Hi Ben,

 

What you have is a wakizashi. The signature reads =93Sanjo Mune=
chika saku.=94
From the quality of the mounts and etc., I am pretty confide=
nt that you have
a sword manufactured for the export market, typically in K=
uwana or some
other local area, and then sent to Yokohama to provide an ine=
xpensive, but
very exotic souvenir for some clipper ship crewman and etc. F=
rom an artistic
and historical level, such swords are not very important. N=
onetheless, they
make nice wall hangers. For the veterans, everyone knows w=
ho Sanjo Munechika
is, so there is no need to explain more, but for the new=
bies, most of these
export swords have the names =96 not signatures =96 of =
big named smiths. Sanjo
Munechika is a Heian period smith who is basically =
the founder of the
Yamashiro tradition. This use of big names is sort of li=
ke a street artist
signing his chalk rendered Rembrandts with Rembrandt=92s=
 name. No one would
mistake this for Munechika=92s work, it just adds a bit=
 of interest.

 

Gordon

h a
> picture tells alot. If it is not possible or practical

cture, you might consider taking it to a
> sword club near you.

> Given =
the size and curvature of the blade, it is
> probably a wakizashi or a nagi=
nata-naoshi (a halberd
> like weapon that has been cut down to make an over=
size
> tanto. "O-tanto" basically is a large or oversized
> tanto). The mou=
nts sound fine to me. Many of these
> came back as souevinirs with WW2 vete=
rans. As they
> played with them over the years, parts <handles,
> seppas, =
etc> got mixed and matched.
> 
> Don't mess with the blade using any cleani=
ng
> chemicals. Despite the polish being gone and the edge
> destroyed, the=
re may be some life left to it.
> 
> Please share in what state or country =
you live, and we
> will try to point you to a nearby sword society or
> clu=
b.
